item.title: FTC Officially Drops Case Against Microsoft Activision Blizzard Acquisition
item.description:
Summary

  • The FTC has dropped the case against Microsoft's Activision Blizzard acquisition.
  • Microsoft continues to make ABK games available on non-Xbox platforms, such as PlayStation.
  • The resolution of the FTC case clears the way for Microsoft and Activision Blizzard to advance their plans for Xbox and multi-platform game releases.

The United States Federal Trade Commission, or FTC, has officially dropped its case opposing Microsoft ’s acquisition of Activision Blizzard. Many people will be surprised that the case was still being pursued, considering that the FTC’s original request for an injunction on the deal was denied in July 2023. Microsoft completed the $68.7 billion acquisition in October of that year, and many Activision Blizzard games have since been released on Xbox Game Pass.

Despite the deal’s seemingly successful completion, the FTC continued to oppose the ABK acquisition, filing an appeal against the injunction ruling a year and a half ago. In early May 2025, an appeals court upheld the original court’s denial of the injunction, with the deciding panel stating that the FTC had failed “to make an adequate showing as to the likelihood of success on the merits as to any of its theories.”

Shortly after that ruling, on May 22, the FTC officially dropped the case against Microsoft, clarifying that “the public interest is best served by dismissing the litigation in this case.” According to the court panel that denied the FTC’s appeal, the government authority had not successfully shown that Microsoft would prevent rival companies from accessing popular franchises like Call of Duty after the Activision Blizzard acquisition.

FTC Stops Opposing Microsoft's Activision Blizzard Deal

On the contrary, Microsoft has continued to make ABK games available on PlayStation and other platforms, with Diablo 4 and Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 launching simultaneously on PC, Xbox, and PlayStation. Even previously Xbox-exclusive games like Senua’s Saga: Hellblade 2 are being released on the PS5 with enhanced features, 60 FPS gameplay, and optimizations for Sony’s console.

Following the FTC’s decision to stop contesting Microsoft’s Activision Blizzard acquisition, Microsoft Vice Chair and President Brad Smith thanked the commission for the resolution. He stated that the move was a “victory for players across the country and for common sense in Washington DC.” Though Head of Microsoft Gaming Phil Spencer has not yet made a comment, he did repost Smith’s comment on Twitter, as did Xbox President Sarah Bond.

For their part, members of the Xbox community are in two camps. Many didn’t even realize there was still a case pending, as Microsoft's ABK acquisition seemed a done deal. Others, who have been following the situation more closely, feel that this resolution was inevitable because the FTC’s case, for all intents and purposes, was already lost two years ago. Either way, as the commission’s challenge was the last major hurdle for the deal, Microsoft and Activision Blizzard can now move forward unhindered with their plans for the future of Xbox, potentially bringing even more exciting titles to Xbox Game Pass and releasing blockbusters on multiple platforms.

item.title: How Doom: The Dark Ages’ Parries Fill a Void Left by Glory Kills
item.description:
In what is surely one of its most divisive points of discourse, Doom: The Dark Ages ’ Glory Strikes, essentially watered-down finishing blows on enemies who’re left dazed (a stun state signified by a purple glow), are composed of swifter yet more lackluster animations that pale in comparison to the creative violence portrayed in Glory Kills. The issue, then, is that Glory Kills were removed with almost no trace in Doom: The Dark Ages — thankfully, this is not without a tenable reason.

Substituting Glory Kills for Glory Strikes makes combat faster with shorter animations, but that’s ironically unnecessary in an installment that’s knowingly and purposefully slower without dashes to facilitate and prioritize parries and melee attacks, though the Doom Slayer’s new sprint and shield launch mechanics do a lot to make up for that. Still, expecting players to parry every green projectile and attack they see on screen wouldn’t be possible if they were watching a one- or two-second Glory Kill animation every five seconds, and Glory Kills, as great as they are in Doom (2016) and Doom Eternal , aren’t missed too much when all of Doom: The Dark Ages ’ combat features come together in unison.

Glory Kills are a Core Part of Doom’s Soft Reboots

Doom (2016) and Doom Eternal ’s Glory Kills are essentially a means of instantly executing a staggered demon while also taking the opportunity to withdraw health from their corpse and bless players with a moment to catch their breath before they continue leaping and dashing around incessantly. Indeed, each entry in Doom’s soft reboot trilogy— Doom (2016), Doom Eternal , and Doom: The Dark Ages— is now tremendously polarizing in the sense that they’re all unique, resulting in pockets of the community inevitably preferring one’s gameplay over another and vice versa.

Some players might enjoy Doom Eternal more than Doom: The Dark Ages because of its cat-and-mouse chases and platforming emphasis, for example, while other players might enjoy Doom (2016), as basic as it is, for now being something of a palate-cleansing neutral ground between its prequel and sequel games. Each is a dish prepared and served in wildly different ways, and what one takes away is often replaced with something that complements that dish far more, even if it’s a tough swallow getting rid of that one star ingredient.

Doom: The Dark Ages Proves Glory Kills are Gratifying, But Not Essential

Doom: The Dark Ages features Glory Strikes, not Glory Kills, distinguished by a lack of gratuitous finisher animations. By default, the Doom Slayer simply kicks the dazed demon or strikes them with the Shield Saw, if not the melee weapon they have equipped. A Glory Strike is different from a dazed execution, however, as it only weakens an enemy and extracts health from them. Either way, while Glory Kills perform basically the same function without a gruesome finisher, it’s highly noticeable how little effort the Slayer commits to eviscerating and demolishing demons this time around.

The closest players can get to achieving what could be considered a Glory Kill is when they land a dazed execution on a demon from above; in such cases, the Doom Slayer invariably bisects or decapitates demons with the Shield Saw, depending on the demon players are executing.

Instead, players are encouraged to indulge in one-on-one engagements after nearby fodder or morale mobs have been dealt with. Parries and melee strikes create a slow-motion effect, too, and extracting health, armor, or ammo is baked into these regular mechanics so that players are never low on any of them, which is easy enough to guarantee when tackling demons formulaically.

Glory Kills, as great as they are in Doom (2016) and Doom Eternal , aren’t missed too much when all of Doom: The Dark Ages ’ combat features come together in unison.

Most enemies can be telegraphed into a series of attacks that exploit and daze them quickly, such as a ‘parry, shoot, strike’ string. But others, like Doom: The Dark Ages ’ Mancubus or Arachnotron, are effortlessly stunned with a Shield Saw throw and slain almost instantly with one or two follow-up Super Shotgun blasts, particularly when both weapons are fully upgraded.

Not unlike Doom Eternal , Doom: The Dark Ages ’ weighty gameplay has a lot going on at any given time, only it is much more manageable with players being incentivized to parry projectiles and strike enemies with melee weapons rather than indulging in a chaotic mix of double-jumps, double-dashes, Chainsaws, Flame Belches, Blood Punches, and Crucibles. Glory Kills might’ve melded well with Doom: The Dark Ages ’ combination of ingredients after all, though they would’ve been yet another dogged animation among foundations, and there are already plenty of epic beats achieved in gameplay.

5 Images
5 Images

item.title: Beginner Tips For Fantasy Life i: The Girl Who Steals Time
item.description:
Summary

  • Pick combat life first for self-protection and easy leveling.
  • Craft better tools to save Dosh and improve quality.
  • Pick up everything, explore islands, progress the story, and try every life.

Fantasy Life I: The Girl Who Steals Time has brought back many players who loved the original Fantasy Life title while also inviting a new audience of players to experience a new life for themselves in a game that explores both the past, present, and an entirely different world.

While Fantasy Life I is an RPG title that can be quite straightforward to understand, there are some interesting tips for beginners of the game that can help out with giving the player the best possible start to their Fantasy Life . From deciding which life to start their adventure with, to how a player should progress through the story, these are some beginner tips for Fantasy Life I: The Girl Who Steals Time .

8 Pick A Combat Life First

Players Need To Be Able To Protect Themselves

When players first start Fantasy Life I , they will be instructed to pick a life for themselves so that they don't become a lazy imp. While it may be tempting to choose one of the gathering or crafting lives first, such as Woodcutter or Blacksmith, players should instead focus their attention on the combat lives.

By selecting something such as Paladin, Mercenary, Hunter, or Magician, a player will be able to protect themselves easily while exploring in Fantasy Life I: The Girl Who Steals Time . This life can also be leveled while focusing on other lives, too.

7 Always Craft Better Tools

Players Can Make Tools Of Different Quality

As players level in their respective lives in Fantasy Life I , players will be required to improve their tools alongside their level. Depending on the life, this tool or weapon will either deal more damage or do its job quicker. Crafting these tools instead of purchasing them is much cheaper and allows the player to save their Dosh for other things.

Although it may be tempting to craft tools that are a different resource, such as Oak Saws being turned into Pine Saws, players should instead focus on mastering the recipe of the previous tool level, as they are far more likely to create a tool or weapon that is of better quality with much cheaper resources.

6 Pick Up Everything

Every Resource Has A Purpose

Another vital beginner's tip, which may seem a little obvious, is making sure the player picks up everything they encounter. From herbs to shells, each resource in Fantasy Life has a purpose, as each thing can be used in one of the many lives available to the player.

Although certain parts of the player's inventory may have a limit on how much can be held, the materials part of the player's inventory does not. Therefore, a player never has to worry about running out of space. Players will be much happier with themselves once they encounter recipes that do need something they have picked up, as they'll be able to craft it instantly.

5 Explore The Islands For Rewards

Players Are Encouraged To Look Around

As players progress through the story of Fantasy Life I , the game will encourage the player to explore more. When in the past of the island the game is set on, a board will appear outside the Guild Office. When interacting with this board, it will give the player various tasks to do around the island.

While some are simple tasks, such as choosing a gathering life or spending a certain amount of money, other tasks encourage the player to visit locations on the island they may not have visited otherwise.

4 Purchase Recipes From Merchants

It's Cheaper In The Long Run

The currency of Dosh is the main way players will purchase various resources, items, and other things from merchants in the main capital of Fantasy Life I . While players may feel tempted to purchase a ready-made weapon or tool from the merchants, they should instead see if they have any recipes available.

Looking for crafting recipes not only means players can make their own custom tools, but many of these recipes are also for crafting furniture, which players can then use to customize their home to give it a more personal touch. They could possibly also make a profit from selling the things they have crafted from these recipes.

3 Progressing The Story Isn't Bad

Player Will Unlock Plenty More To Explore

Although it's tempting to hold off from completing any of the stories in Fantasy Life , players shouldn't be afraid to progress through certain elements of the story. By attempting to remain in the past, players miss out on an entirely new world to explore, as well as one of the biggest mechanics of the game involving people known as Stranglings.

Progressing the story will also eventually unlock two other brand-new lives for the player to experience, with both also being incredibly useful when managing their own island. Players should at least proceed through the start of the game, as this is when Fantasy Life truly opens up.

2 Try Out Every Life

Lives Work Well Together

It costs nothing to change to a different life in Fantasy Life , so a player shouldn't limit the number of lives they take part in. Every life gives the player a different set of adorable clothing and an assortment of tasks to complete to better themselves in that life.

Besides the enjoyment factor of each and every life in this RPG, many of the lives work well together. For example, the Woodcutter life is a useful gathering life to have. By having this life, the player can chop trees. These resources can then be used by the Carpenter life to create not only furniture, but also the weapons used by both Hunters and Magicians.

1 Adventure At The Player's Own Pace

Having Fun Is The Most Important Tip

Out of all the tips that can be given for Fantasy Life I: The Girl Who Steals Time , one of the best tips that can be given is that players should be sure to adventure at their own pace. In the latest game of the Fantasy Life franchise, there is plenty to be done, both within and outside the main story.

With players having the freedom to travel through time and to other realms, players can truly make a life for themselves however they wish. Discovering all this game has in store is something that can't be rushed.

item.title: Genshin Impact Artist Reimagines Kokomi as a Majestic Dragon
item.description:
Summary

  • An artist transformed Genshin Impact's Kokomi into a dragon.
  • Kokomi's dragon form fits the Water Dragon archetype and reflects her in-game colors.
  • Kokomi has become more popular due to new Dendro elemental reactions, anticipated on the Chronicled Banner.

A talented Genshin Impact artist has transformed the fan-favorite Sangonomiya Kokomi into a majestic dragon. Genshin Impact is known for having a community that often creates new character concepts or reimagines existing characters in creative ways.

Kokomi has been part of the game since the Inazuma arc and was officially released in the second part of Version 2.1, the same update that introduced the Inazuma Archon, Raiden Shogun. According to the official lore, Kokomi is the Divine Priestess of Watatsumi Island and a descendant of the renowned Sangonomiya Clan.

A Reddit user named Menulia has shared an impressive artwork that depicts what Genshin Impact 's five-star Kokomi might look like as a divine dragon. The dragon features lavender and pearl-blue scales, which mirror Kokomi's in-game color scheme. In terms of dragon types, Kokomi’s new form could fit the Water Dragon archetype, which makes sense given her ties to the sea. The post gained significant attention on the official Genshin Impact subreddit, gathering over 1,000 upvotes. The artist revealed that they drew Kokomi as a sort of ritual to improve their chances of acquiring this five-star character, as HoYoverse confirmed she will appear on the Chronicled Banner. The post also includes a previous dragon concept for Kokomi, created by the artist back in 2021, with many comments noting that the new version is a major improvement.

Genshin Impact's Kokomi Transformed Into a Dragon

Menulia revealed that the ritual has worked for her in the past, with the most recent success being the acquisition of Genshin Impact 's Geo user Navia. Many fans were excited about the return of the Chronicled Banner, as it is HoYoverse's method of featuring five-star characters who have not appeared on the limited banner for a long time. With the pool of playable characters constantly expanding, many of them often go years without a rerun on the limited banner.

While many players hoped that HoYoverse would introduce a triple-banner mechanic instead of the current double-banner system to address this issue, it seems that the Chronicled Banner will become a standard feature, at least for the foreseeable future. Currently, Kokomi is one of the most anticipated characters, especially among long-time players. However, that wasn’t the case when she was first released, particularly since her debut followed the release of Genshin Impact 's Inazuma Archon.

Fortunately, the introduction of new Dendro elemental reactions has significantly improved her combat effectiveness, as she is now considered one of the best Bloom characters in Genshin Impact . Players who want to add Kokomi to their roster will need to wait for Phase 2 of the current update, which is scheduled to arrive on May 27.

Step into Teyvat, a vast world teeming with life and flowing with elemental energy.

You and your sibling arrived here from another world. Separated by an unknown god, stripped of your powers, and cast into a deep slumber, you now awake to a world very different from when you first arrived.

Thus begins your journey across Teyvat to seek answers from The Seven — the gods of each element. Along the way, prepare to explore every inch of this wondrous world, join forces with a diverse range of characters, and unravel the countless mysteries that Teyvat holds...

item.title: Shuten Order - Official Announcement Trailer
item.description: Shuten Order is a unique game that combines five adventures into one, each with its own gameplay style. Watch the official announcement trailer here.
